making that vision reality but before I
go to the vision piece I just wanted to take a second to introduce ourself
briefly who is digital divide data or by the way we just say DDD that's it's much
easier to say so we are not-for-profit
organization we around since about 15 years and the organization was founded
by a gentleman called Jeremy Hawkins team was with us who by the way is the
CEO and the founder and the the focus
really here is you know being a social enterprise so if you look at us
from a business perspective what we are doing essentially is providing BPO or IT
services to customers around the globe
we are operating out of four different
locations four offices essentially Kenya
is the office Teresa has talked about but we also have offices in Cambodia and
Laos all Asia and we just - a couple of years ago we introduced new offices here
in Virginia which I'm going to talk about it in a second we are generating
about fourteen million dollar revenues which were using to fund our social
mission and today we have approximately a thousand young people who are employed
by us so we are a very small company we
are trying to do a very big impact and over the last couple of years we got
several awards and recognitions which we are for sure very proud of
I personally joined IDI just about two years ago and as I was introduced I did
spend 25 years of my life in a BPO company computer science and I was at
the point in my career where I said you know running from earnings to earnings and going from quarterly reports to
quarterly meetings is that really what I want to do for the rest of my life is there nothing I can personally do to
help to do a little bit good for the world and then I came across Jeremy's
organization which totally inspired me in and tricked me because he was
focusing over more than a decade already on developing young people so I decided
to to let the commercial side go and started my life in the NGO community two
years ago and I have to say it was probably the most meaningful two years of my career so when you look at us from
the social angle our social mission then the ultimate philosophy of TDD is and
has always been to provide employment on one side but then also to provide
education and enable education for underserved communities and when I say
underserved communities then it is really when you look to Kenya or Asia
then it's really about young very
talented young people but essentially very poor most of our students and
employees in those regions are coming out of the slums they do not have
essentially any possibility for any education by themselves so they have not
a chance really to learn anything or become a meaningful job and that's the
population Teresa referred to who are essentially living on a dollar a day or sometimes even less than seven so we are
really focusing on helping those students to get a higher education we
provide scholarships for them and based on their education then they create we
create an opportunity for them really to have you know very higher earnings and
way better life for themselves if you look at our offices in Virginia the
principle is the same we are focusing on employment and education but here the
target group is a little bit different in Virginia we are focusing on spouses
military spouses who are following their husband's around the world but also US
veterans Jeremy has created that organization I think four or five years
ago that is rapidly growing as well and we are focusing particularly on those
target groups so when you are providing
BPO services or IT services like we do as the vehicle to fund your social
mission then you have many challenges but one of the manger you have is really trying to stay
relevant with the services you want to provide to your customers so in the past
we have largely provided we have been largely providing you know content management services web and research
services but you have to keep pace with the industry and technology really to
not become a commodity and then you are forced down to you know only compete on the price so we have been sitting down a
year ago discussing you know what is really the next kind of skill sets we
need to bring to our students so that we can you know provide a relevant service
to our customers but also maybe what could be a skill set which we can teach
our students which is may way more relevant than the studies they do you
can imagine if you study business engineering in Kenya and you get your
you'll get your graduation and you enter into a market with 60% unemployment your
education is you know it's nice but it's not really making the difference so the idea was twofold to say what is the
skill set which is going to be needed from a consumer perspective and what is
really skills which help our students to to advance in life and you know I said
to my management team clearly cloud is up there everything around the cloud is
totally in demand and totally hip and within the cloud there's only one company who is really totally up there
that's Amazon AWS so why don't we go and create a center of excellence of AWS in
Kenya like Theresa said so I remember that day because my management team was
sitting there around the table and they were looking at me saying what this what did this guy smoke this morning when he
get out of that and they were right to some extent because you know as I
described our students are coming out of the slumps now these kids and I respectfully
always call them kids they're all young adults but but essentially these kids they do not have any exposure to
technology and some of them come to us and have not even seen a keyboard before
all right so that is really the starting point which we have to start to educate
our students but we said you know why
this underserved population not also have the chance to participate on such a
booming market like AWS you know what what kind of hindering smoovies you know
are there to not help them to teach those skill sets so he gave it a try and
launched what we call the academy in Kenya we did this January this year we
picked basically randomly 30 of our students we hired an AWS architect an
expert again with the help of AWS we found a young expert that he was based
in South Africa he was Kenyan and he wanted to go back to Kenya so we we got
the needed subject matter expertise on board and then we started to design the
curriculum and as you can imagine the standard curriculum didn't make it
because our starting point was chosen to be so low so so we created the
curriculum which was a combination out of you know trained elite trainer led
sessions web-based sessions we did do a lot of team work sessions around and we
also used a lot of you know tech mock tests ready to figure out is the pace of
our teaching is it too fast do we need to slow down so we really wanted to see you know how the students
going to pick up now if anyone of you have ever interacted with young people
out of the slums they may be poor but they have one tremendous thing in common
and that is that easier to learn that desire to promote themselves and if you
offer these kids an opportunity they put hundred and fifty percent into it so we
run the program about six months we could have been faster if he only wanted
them to pass the test but we really wanted to give them a competence so so
prepare them really to you know provide a job in the future not just to pass the
test so coming June we started to get them through the official certification
process and I can tell you I had no idea what's going to come out I I know I had
a call with the kids and look guys be relaxed whatever is going to come out of

was 98 percent 97 percent 95 percent they really nailed it and you know we

by far exceeded all my personal imaginations I thought if I can find if
I can get 10 out of 30 through a program like this that would be for me already
